loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre is 32 years old and married; he has one child who is one year old. He owns a business selling groceries. He has two years of experience and works from 6 a.m until 6 p.m every day except Sunday. 

Jean Pierre has requested a Kiva loan through the Vision Finance Company so that he can buy more juice, Fanta, beer and other drinks for resale. Through this expansion, Jean Pierre will be able to earn more profits, which will be used to expand his supermarket business and save for his future.

loans.use: to purchase more juice, Fanta, beer, and other drinks for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more sugar, rice, potatoes, salt, soap etc. to sell.

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr: Revendeur d’articles scolaires dans une boutique, Kossi âgé de 30ans est marié une styliste –modéliste. Il n’a pas d’enfants en charge. C’est en 2009 qu’il a commencé son activité et il s’y plait bien car cela lui procure des revendus lui permettant d’assurer les besoins primaires de la famille. En plus de la vente des articles scolaires, il fait de la photocopie aux étudiants et à toutes personnes. C’est justement pour l’achat d’une machine à photocopier qu’il fait un crédit à WAGES. Comme perspectives d’avenir, il veut créer d’autres points pour la photocopie et assurer un avenir meilleur à la famille.
texts.en: A seller of school supplies with a small shop, Kossi, 30, is married to a fashion designer. He is not raising any children. He began his business in 2009 and he feels very good about it because it brings in enough income to cover the basic needs of his family. Besides selling school supplies, he also makes photocopies for students and for whoever else needs them. It is precisely in order to buy a photocopier that he has taken out a loan from WAGES. As far as his plans for the future go, he would like to open up other venues for photocopying and ensure a better future for his family.

loans.use: to buy a photocopier

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 42 years old and married with one child who is 8 years old. She sells bread, tea and beans in a store she operates from 6 a.m until 8 p.m every day. She currently employs five people to help her and she has two years of experience in this work.  

Catherine has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy more quantities of tea, bread and beans to resell. She plans to use any profits generated from this loan to satisfy her family's basic needs and to pay for medical insurance.

loans.use: to purchase more tea, bread and beans for resale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a married woman who has three children. She describes herself as humble.  She operates a retail store where she sells home products. Her business is located within an urban area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds to improve her retail business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy home products. Her business goal is to be a successful businesswoman  within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy home products to sell.

loans.name: Prodige Baco Group

texts.en:
Esther, aged 46, is the chairwoman of the Community Bank named “Prodige Baco”, which is composed of 15 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Esther has been in the business world since 1997. She manages her business in the northeastern part of Lubumbashi. She is a loyal client of the MFI HOPE RDC and has already received a loan and has repaid it properly. She intends to use the next loan to increase the inventory of her goods by buying some baskets of fish and boxes of chickens for resale, with the aim of increasing her profits. Each week, her business brings in a profit of about US$40. 
Her ambition is to develop it and become financially independent. Esther is married and has five children, who are aged between 4 and 15 years old. Two of them go to school.

loans.use: to increase the inventory of her goods by purchasing some baskets of fish and boxes of chickens for resale.

loans.name: Petronille

texts.en:
Petronille is 40 years old and married with five children, who are between 6 and 15 years old. Her business is well organized and she sells clothes in the market. 
Petronille has requested a loan from Kiva lenders through Vision Finance Company to buy more clothes for resale. With the profit from this loan, she will be able to reinvest in her business, pay her children's school fees and save for her future.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Priscillah

texts.en:
Priscillah is a married woman. She has 3 children. She describes herself as humble. She operates a retail stall where she sells vegetables and cereals such as potatoes, maize, beans, black beans, and other items. Her business is located within an urban area and her primary customers are local residents. 

She describes her biggest business challenge as insufficient funds for improving her business. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy vegetables and grains. Her business goal is to be a successful businesswoman within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and grains.

loans.name: Namiq

texts.en:
Namiq is a 30-year-old man who is married and has two daughters. He is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with his family in the Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. He breeds cows and cattle and sells milk and milk products as well as cattle for meat purposes to local butchers. Namiq has six years of experience in this field thanks to his father, who taught him the best ways to look after cattle. He receives 60 AZN financial support from the government monthly, but this is too low to cover family needs.

Namiq usually buys small cattle, raises and fattens them for five to six months, and then resells them at a profit in the local livestock bazaar. He sells milk and yogurt to his neighbors. Milk and meat selling brings in 150 AZN income per month. Milk and yogurt, as well as meat, are very popular products in Azerbaijan. People use meat in everyday national dishes, such as pilau and dolma, and always use yogurt sauce. Milk products are considered very healthy and are also present in everyday life.   

This is his family's only source of income and is not enough to cover the basic needs of his beloved children. Namiq applied for a 2200 AZN loan to purchase three cattle and two milking cows.

loans.use: to purchase three cattle and two milking cows.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma, 20, is the mother of one child. She lives with her husband, Bakari, and their son in the town of Msambweni.

Fatuma used to be a housewife but a few weeks ago, an idea came to her to start a cosmetics shop. She intends to sell creams, lotions, hair conditioner and beauty products for women and men. She has a small store where she wants to sell from.

Fatuma has requested a 30,000 KES loan. She believes that with financial help she’ll attain what she needs.

loans.use: to buy creams, lotions, hair conditioner and beauty products.

loans.name: Hidayat

texts.en:
Hidayat is 44 years old and an IDP (internally displaced person) who lives in Bilasuvar IDP Settlement with his wife and three children. He is a farmer and has raised seasonal fruits and vegetables for the last 10 years. During these years, Hidayat gained enough skills and experience to run the business. He chose farming because it is profitable and fresh fruits and vegetables are in high demand. 
People use fresh vegetables everyday and consider them healthy. Many national dishes are made of vegetables, like pilau and dolma. Fresh fruits serve every table in Azerbaijan family and are also used to make fresh punch. He usually sells his crop in the central bazaar. His monthly income is 100 AZN.
As these products are in high demand, Hidayat wants to expand his business and produce more fruits and vegetables to cover market demand. For this purpose, he applied for a loan of 1450 AZN. He will buy new garden tools, seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy new garden tools, seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Mena Group

texts.en: In the photo are members of the “Mena” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. This is not the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With their previous Kiva loan, they were able to add more inventory to their respective businesses. This led to a great improvement in their businesses and lives through increased sales and profits. They were able to use the extra profit they made to send their children to school, feed and clothe them. Having repaid that loan successfully, they are requesting a new loan of 3,600,000 Leones for the entire group. With this new loan, they will be able to further expand their business inventories. Fatmata remains the featured leader of this group. Fatmata sells market food and will use her share of the loan to further increase her inventories.

loans.use: to buy firewood, rice, onions, margi, cigarettes, etc. in large quantities to add to her business

loans.name: Komla

texts.fr: Revendeur de produits d’alimentation générale, Komla est un jeune marié de 27 ans et père d’un seul enfant de 01 an. Il exerce cette activité depuis 2005. Il sollicite son quatrième prêt auprès de WAGES pour élargir et  diversifier son commerce. Il compte réinvestir ses bénéfices dans son activité et assurer l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en: A retail grocer, Komla is a young married man, 27 years old, and the father of one child, who is  a year old. Komla has been in this business since 2005. He is requesting his fourth loan from WAGES to expand and diversify his business. He intends to reinvest his profits in his business and ensure his children's education.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items to sell

loans.name: Adjo

texts.fr: Revendeuse de tubercules, Adjo  âgée de 58 ans, a débuté cette activité depuis 1974 et dispose d’une place dans un marché. Elle est mariée à un représentant commercial  et ont 05 enfants. Elle sollicite son premier crédit auprès de WAGES pour l’achat des tubercules. Elle recherche à travers les bénéfices de ce prêt, la sécurité alimentaire de sa famille et le développement de son activité.
texts.en:
Adjo, who is 58 years old, has been a reseller of tubers since 1974. She has a stand in a market. 

She is married to a sales representative and they have 5 children. 

She is asking for a first loan with WAGES to buy tubers. With the profits from this loan, she is looking to have enough to eat and to develop her business.

loans.use: to buy tubers.

loans.name: Kougbafo

texts.fr: Revendeuse de pagnes de façon ambulante, Kougbafo âgée de 35ans est mariée à un employé dans une société de la place. Elle  a 03 enfants âgés respectivement de 12,10 et 08ans tous scolarisés. Avec son premier crédit à WAGES, elle va s’approvisionner en pagnes pour revendre à ses clients. Elle voudrait à l’avenir, ouvrir une boutique et aider son mari dans l’éducation de leurs enfants. Elle est dans  ce domaine il y a 12ans.
texts.en: A street seller of pagnes (colourful West African cloth), Kougbafo is 35 years old and married to an employee of a local company. She has 3 children aged 12, 10 and 8, who all go to school. She will use her first loan from WAGES to stock up on pagnes to resell to her customers. In the future, she would like to open a shop and support her husband with their children's education. She has been in her line of work for 12 years.

loans.use: to buy pagnes.

loans.name: Venant

texts.en:
Venant is 47 years old, married and has seven children between 5 and 19 years old. He is known for selling local drinks. He has two years of experience and he works from 7 a.m until 7 p.m every day except on Sunday. 

Venant has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to buy large quantities of sorghum to make local drinks to sell. With this loan, he will hopefully earn more profits which. in turn, will allow him to keep reinvesting for better financial stability. In addition to that, he will continue improving his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy large quantities of sorghum to make local drinks to sell.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is 36 years old and married with one child who is 4 years old. He sells bread and tea from a store that he operates from 6:00 a.m until 6 p.m every day. He currently employs one person to help him and he has 3 years of experience in this work.  

Innocent has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via the Vision Finance Company in order to buy more tea and bread to resell. He plans to use any profits generated from this loan to satisfy his family's basic needs and to pay for medical insurance.

loans.use: to purchase more tea and bread to sell.

loans.name: Wayan

texts.en:
Wayan is a Balinese artisan who specializes in batik and beaded baskets and handbags. She would like to invest in the purchase of such raw materials as beads and baskets for production.

Wayan has been selling through NOVICA since 2002. This is her story:

"After I got married I started to learn beadwork techniques from my mother-in-law. Most people in my husband's village earn their living from beadwork. After six months of learning, I was able to create new designs. My favorite designs are flowers, thunder, balls, mountain, stars and many more."

"At the moment it's difficult to obtain the baskets I need for the beadwork, as they are hand-woven in a village on another island. That is why I'm very happy to receive this microcredit, because it will make it possible to buy larger amounts of baskets and beads in advance. My team will be happy and motivated too. Thank you very much for your support."

Use the link below to view Wayan's beaded, woven and batik accessories on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/artistdetail/index.cfm?faid=3458

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of such raw materials as beads and baskets for production

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be humble. She operates a retail store where she sells home products. Her business is located within an urban area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy home products for sale. Her business goal is to improve her business within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy home products for sale

loans.name: Las Rositas De Laderas De Chillon Group

texts.es:
¡Saludos desde Perú! Este es el grupo Las Rositas de Laderas De Chillón
Florencia de 41 años es casada y tiene una hija. Ella tiene su propio negocio un bazar con el nombre de su hija “BAZAR ALEXANDRA” allí vende toda clase de artículos como regalos y ropa, son 12 años que tiene el negocio y le va muy bien, sus asiduos clientes son vecinos del lugar y amigos  quienes acuden a comprarle. Ella se esmera en brindarle  buen trato y atención para poder mantener su clientela, por otro lado también para algunas personas,  gracias a sus ingresos  puede ayudar a su familia sobre todo a su hija ya que su mayor sueño es verla convertida en una profesional, el préstamo que ha solicitado lo utilizara para mejorar su negocio con la compra de mercadería para su bazar. Ella está feliz por continuar con su negocio y en un futuro le gustaría ampliarlo.
¡Florencia agradece su apoyo!

*Florencia viste polo negro.
texts.en:
Greetings from Peru!  This is Las Rositas de Laderas de Chillón Group.

Florencia, 41, is married and has a daughter.  She has her own business, a variety store with her daughter's name, Bazar Alexandra.  She sells all types of things there, such as gifts and clothing.  She has had the business for 12 years and it's going very well for her.  Her devoted customers are neighbors and friends who come to buy from her.  She goes to a lot of trouble to treat and serve them well so she can keep her clientele.  Thanks to her income she can help her family, especially her daughter, because her biggest dream is to see her become a professional.

She will use the loan she has requested to improve her business by buying merchandise for her store.  She's happy about continuing with her business and would like to expand it in the future. 

Florencia is grateful for your help!

*Florencia is wearing a black polo shirt.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her variety store

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is married and has five children. She lives with them and her husband in the town of Msambweni located in the coastal region of Kenya.
She currently gets income from selling fish from her home. In addition, she also sells makuti (palm fronds). She works for over eight hours a day. Her husband and her need to cover the food, education, and medical expenses for their family. 
The loan she is requesting is to buy a frying pan, cooking oil, more fish and makuti.

loans.use: to buy a frying pan, cooking oil, more fish and makuti.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a cow.

loans.name: Miatta

texts.en: Miatta is 33 years old and lives in New Kru Liberia. She is single and stopped her education at 7th grade. For the past six years she has been running a shop where she sells clothes and other items. She started this business with the little money that she received from her boyfriend and learned the ways of selling from her mother. She is very happy with her business because she makes a lot of profit and learns different local languages from her customers. She is requesting a loan to buy more clothes, handkerchiefs, socks, head-ties to expand her business. Her plans are to expand her business and build her house.

loans.use: to buy more clothes, handkerchiefs, socks, head-ties to expand her business.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet has been running a private medical clinic for the past ten and half years with the monthly income of KES. 20,000 which she uses to support her family. 

She is applying for her second loan from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loan successfully. Violet will use the loan to buy medical equipment. 

She will plough back the anticipated profit into the business. Her hopes and dreams are to expand the business and improve the family living standard.

loans.use: to buy medical equipment

loans.name: Kmzm Progressive Group

texts.en:
This is 29-year-old Rambidzai from Mutare, the capital of Minicaland province in Zimbabwe. She is married with three children, two attending school.  Rambidzai runs a business selling clothes. She says the main challenges faced are high custom duties at the South African border. 

Rambidzai has requested a loan of $600 to purchase clothes from South Africa for resale in Zimbabwe. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to complete the family house which is presently under construction. In the future Rambidzai plans to have her own boutique.

loans.use: to purchase clothes in South Africa for resale

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is a 45-year-old married man. He has nine children, with ages ranging from 2 years to 22 years. He describes himself to be a creative and industrious man.  

He operates a retail business where he sells windows, doors, and cooking pots.  He has been involved in this business for 22 years and employs four  staff members. His business is located within a busy town, and his primary customers are local residents . He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient materials for welding. 

He will use the KES 12,900 loan to buy a solar lamp to be used by his family members. 

His business goal is to run his own welding company within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will expand his business.

loans.use: To buy a solar lamp.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be a humble woman. She operates a retail store where she sells home products. She has been involved in this business for seven years. Her business is located at an urban area, and her primary customers are local residents. 

Mercy describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the 10,000 Kes (Kenyan shillings) loan to buy home products for resale. Her business goal is to improve her business within five years. She hopes that, in the future, she will be successful in her business. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy home products for resale.

loans.name: Geoginer

texts.en: Geoginer is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself as honest. She operates a food stall where she sells vegetables and fruits, such potatoes, cabbages, tomatoes, etc. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in an open-air market,  and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge as a shortage of vegetables and fruits to sell. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy vegetables and fruits to sell. Her business goal is to run a successful business within five years. She hopes she will improve her business in the future. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and fruits for resale.

loans.name: Bobby

texts.en: Bobby is 27 years old and single. He is a resident Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. For the past two years, Bobby has owned and operated a motorcycle transport business to earn a living. Each month, he earns 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Bobby been a member of GDMPC since 2010. Bobby is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan to purchase vehicle spare parts to maintain his transport business. In the future, he wants to save his revenue for his future family.

loans.use: to purchase vehicle spare parts to maintain his transport business.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en: Gemma is married and the mother of three children. She is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines, where she has run a retail business for six years and earns about 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. She has requested a loan for 5,500 PHP to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee. In 2011, Gemma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and her living conditions. In the future, she hopes to improve her family's life.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
This is Thelma. She previously accessed a 40,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP for her to buy more merchandise items and products to increase her product inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Thelma hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to have a happy family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for merchandise items and products needed in her business

loans.name: Fransisca

texts.en:
Fransisca is a 27-year-old single woman. She describes herself to be humble. She operates a retail store where she sells home products such as sugar, salt, flour, etc. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located at an urban area, and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. 

She will use the 20,000 Kes (Kenyan shillings) loan to buy home products. Her business goal is to expand her business within five years.

loans.use: to buy retail products.

loans.name: Mamie

texts.en:
Mamie, 41, resides with her husband at West Point. She has six children that are between the ages of five and 24. Only two of the children live with her at home, and are in school. The other four children live with other  relatives. 

She has been involved in this business for the past four years; selling (imported) slippers, skirts, and blouses at the market. What she loves most about her business is that she can have more customers, so she make profits every day. With the profits she buy more goods, and help her husband with the household expenses. She is requesting a loan to purchase more (imported) slippers, blouses, and skirts. Her plan for the future is to become a big business woman.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing to sell.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor, 26, is a farmer in Litein county in Kenya where he lives with his wife. 

He has been practicing mixed farming for the past four years, producing milk, tea and pineapples, which he sells at the local market in his area. He also runs a motorbike transportation business and buys and sells tea as an additional source of income.

He is requesting 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase materials for constructing a dairy unit which is a housing unit usually done in two sections with one part being mainly for feeding and the other for protection against rain for his dairy cows, which will help in more production. He also believes he will have bought another quality dairy cow that produces high quality milk in the next five years, hence more income that will help him improve on his standard of living and be able to pay for his children’s school fees.

Competition and lack of finances are his major challenges in farming.

Victor is very thankful to Juhudi kilimo for providing the loan.

loans.use: To purchase materials for constructing a dairy unit.

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Bernard, 34 years old, is a married man. He has seven children, with ages ranging from 3 years to 14 years. He describes himself as a quiet man. He operates a motorcycle providing transportation services. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located within a busy area and his primary customers are local residents from the environs. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insecurity within the area. He will use this 10,000 Kenyan shilling loan to buy motorcycle spare parts. His business goal is to run a spare parts retail store within five years. He hopes that in the future he will educate his children to university level. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: Raymond

texts.en:
Raymond is a married man with six children ranging from 18 to 35 years. He describes himself to be faithful and hard-working. He operates a retail store and a motorcycle business, selling home products and providing transportation. He has been involved in this business for two years and employs five staff members. His business is located in a potential market and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the increasing prices of spare parts. 

He will use the KES 12,900 loan to buy a solar lamp which will be used by his family members. His business goal is to expand his business within five years.

loans.use: to buy a solar lamp.

loans.name: Las Manzanas Group

texts.en:
Silvia is part of the Las Manzanas, a group from the rural community of Patzún, Chimaltenango, located in the central region of Guatemala. This area is known for their large avocado plantations, as well as their colorful dress. Many women weave red, yellow, and purple huipiles. Las Manzanas, is a group filled with energetic women, ready to take on the challenges of the business world. When asked if they liked being a member of the group, with all smiles, the answer was a unanimous “Yes".

Silvia, though shy at first, actively engaged in trying to solve her personal and business problems with the support of her group. Recently widowed and having her only son live an hour away, Silvia found herself at an impasse. She had been a housewife all her life. Occasionally, she had some chickens that she sold in a nearby market, but she never thought she would one day be without her husband. Though she says that at first she struggled, she got up and decided to start, not one business, but two. Barely six months after losing her husband, Silvia has a small animal husbandry business, as well as a tortilla bakery. She currently runs them both from her home but says she hopes to one day find small shop where she can sell her tortillas. Having proven to herself that she can do it on her own, she seems more confident that her future is bright. 

Silvia is so proud to have found Friendship Bridge on her way. It is giving her an opportunity to have a loan so she could increase her two businesses, and so to make a living. This loan will help Silvia to buy some chickens, and to buy corn for her tortilleria business.

The trust bank Las Manzanas, appreciate the hand up that the KIVA investors are giving them, because this will help them, therefore also their families.

loans.use: to buy some chickens, and corn.

loans.name: Robby

texts.en:
Robby works hard to support his family. He runs a general store in Chawama, a highly populated compound in Lusaka, Zambia. He is 40 years old, married, and has two children. 

Robby has been running his business for eleven years now. In his shop, he also offers mobile money transfers through Zoona. He became an agent in the year 2009 when Zoona, then called Mobile Transactions, was starting out. Being a mobile money agent means that Robby provides the service of mobile money transfers to his community and gets a commission for every transaction he does. Robby says offering mobile money transfers at his general shop sets him apart from other general shops in the area. He believes that part of the reason he has stayed in business and been able to compete with big supermarkets is the relationship he has with people.

He needs the Kiva loan so that he can increase his working capital, and earn more commissions. This will help Robby order more grocery stock for his shop, as this is his only source of income.

Robby aspires to one day own a big supermarket, where customers can walk in and do their shopping freely.

loans.use: to increase his working capital so that he can order more grocery stock.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en: Loreta is 45 years old and married. She is from Prenza, Tangub City. She has two grown children who have helped her take care of their bananas. They been in raising bananas for 10 years and earns 3,000 PHP a month. In 2011, Loreta joined GDMPC. She has requested a loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer, and for weeding costs. She hopes for a bountiful harvest, and to expand her cultivated area.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, and for weeding costs.

loans.name: Jimbutch

texts.en: Jimbutch, 38 years old, is a married entrepreneur of Stimpson, Ozamis City with two children. He earns revenue from his transport service business. It has existed for almost three years now and he earn 4,000 PHP a month. To improve his business, he borrows amount of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC micro credit to obtain accessories and tires. He joined GDMPC micro credit in 2010. Before long, he’s hopeful of the possibility of expanding his business.

loans.use: to obtain accessories and tires.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
This is Emma. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy products like meat, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household, and business expenditures. 
She would now like to apply for a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients and supplies needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 
Emma hopes to grow her business and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is 49 years old and married with one child.
She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Carmelita is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.
Carmelita has been farming rice for seven years, and she also earns additional income from a general store.
She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: María Dolores

texts.es:
La Señora. María es una socia que conforma el banco comunal El Control hace un año, le gusta mucho la banca comunal porque son un grupo muy unido, vive  por la comunidad de Punta Corral que pertenece a la parroquia de Turi en Cuenca, lugar que es conocido como el mirador de la ciudad ya que desde allí se puede admirar una gran parte de la ciudad de Cuenca, su gente se dedica a la crianza de animales, agricultura y comercio.

La Señora María tiene 32 años, es casada y fruto de su unión conyugal ha concebido 2 hijos de 15 y 4 años de edad, su primer hijo está estudiando en el colegio y su segundo hijo está en la guardería. Su esposo labora en la rama de la construcción como albañil, la casa en la que viven es propiedad conyugal.

Doña María pasa en casa al cuidado de sus hijos pero d para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar se dedica a la crianza de pollos y cuyes, también siembra hortalizas en sus terrenos las mismas que luego las vende en un mercado de la ciudad.
 
Su crédito lo va a invertir  en la compra de cobijas para dedicarse a la venta de esta mercadería e iniciar con este nuevo negocio. 

Su sueño es crecer en la venta de este producto y llegar a tener un almacén.
texts.en:
María has been a member of the "El Control" communal bank for a year. She likes the communal bank very much because they are a close-knit group. She lives in the community of Punta Corral, which is part of the Turi parish in Cuenca, a place known as the city's viewpoint, as from there one can admire a great part of the city of Cuenca. Its people raise animals, farm, and engage in commercial activities.

María is 32 years old, married and has two children ages 15 and 4. Her eldest child is going to school and her second child is in daycare. Her husband works in the construction field as a bricklayer. They own the house where they live.

María spends her time at home looking after her children, but to help her husband with the household expenses she raises chickens and guinea pigs. She also grows vegetables on her parcel of land, which she then sells at a market in the city.

She is going to use her loan to purchase blankets, so that she can sell this merchandise and begin this new business.

Her goal is to increase sales of this product and eventually have a store.

loans.use: To buy blankets to sell.

loans.name: Olive

texts.en: Olive is 31 years old, and a very industrious mother of two children. She has a business where she sells snacks and groceries in the market. She uses the income she generates from her business carefully, for her business and for her children’s education. In order to increase her income, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP to buy additional groceries such as breads, junk foods, noodles, soft drinks, vegetables, and meat (to cook). She hopes that she can get the amount that she has requested in order to further develop her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of groceries such as breads, junk foods, noodles, soft drinks, vegetables, and meat (to cook)

loans.name: Rhiza Mae

texts.en: Rhiza Mae is 19 years old, single and an entrepreneur in Magsaysay, Pana-on. She earns income from her transport service business. She has had her business for almost a year now and she earns 3,000 a month. To improve business, she has asked to borrow 8,000 PHP from GDMPC micro credit which she just recently joined. She would like the loan to buy accessories and tires. She is hopeful about the possibility of expanding her business before long.

loans.use: to buy accessories and tires

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is a 49-year-old married woman from Cortes, Bohol. She has four children. She raises hogs. She has been in the hog-raising business for twenty years. She requested a loan of 9,000 PHP to buy feeds and food supplements. Cecilia would like to expand her business to support her family as well as to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy feeds and food supplements

loans.name: Lonie

texts.en: Lonie's main source of income comes from his gardening business. He is 31 years old, married and from Macabayao, Jimenez. He has been gardening for three years and earns 3,200 a month. In 2011, Lonie joined GDMPC. Lonie is requesting a loan of 8,000 which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es: El señor Daniel de 21 años de edad conviviente con la señora Clementina hace 5 años atrás, ambos con una instrucción de nivel primario, tienen 2 hijas pequeños, viven en Colomi Comunidad Palta Loma hacia el norte lado Escuelita.Don Daniel y su conviviente son una familia humilde de bajos recursos económicos se dedican a la actividad agrícola durante el año sus ingresos son estacionales por la venta de papa, oca y papaliza sembrando en terreno herencia de sus padres de 1,5 has, como también cuentan con cabezas de ganado vacuno 2 lecheras más 2 de engorde de esta manera ellos viven; El señor Daniel y su esposa pasaron a consultar un crédito que necesitaban para hacer construir una vivienda ya que su ambiente que viven es de malas condiciones ellos necesitan mejorar. Ello quiere una casita mejor para estar mas seguros además ellos mencionan que quieren formar una familia.
texts.en: Daniel is 21 years old, and he has been living together with Clementina for 5 years. They both finished primary school. They have 2 young daughters. They live in Colomi, in the Palta Loma community, toward the north side of Escuelita. Daniel and his partner are a humble, low income family. They are farmers. During the year their income is seasonal, selling potatoes, oca, and papaliza [tubers similar to potatoes]. They plant on land they inherited from their parents, 1.5 hectares; they also have 2 milk cows and 2 cattle for fattening; this is how they make a living. Daniel and his wife came to consult about a loan they needed to build a house, because the house they live in is in bad shape and they need an improvement. They want a better house so they can be more secure, and they also mention that they would like to get married.

loans.use: to build his house.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is married with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Jennifer is 35 years old and has two children who are in school.

Jennifer has a general store business in the Philippines. She requested a loan of 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase more items to sell like noodles, eggs, spices, and cream.

Jennifer has been in this business for three years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell like noodles, eggs, spices, and cream.

loans.name: Everlyn

texts.en:
Everlyn is 27 years old and married with two children.
Everlyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a loan of 17000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell for her store, such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, etc.
Everlyn has borrowed and paid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from food vending and raising pigs.
Everlyn aspires to save money and to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Brenda's Group

texts.en:
Brenda's group is comprised of 5 hard working women. Brenda is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kititale in the region of Uganda. For the past year, Brenda has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells general goods needed around the house. 

To help expand her business, Brenda has requested a loan of 300000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a refrigerator and washing machine, and will help Brenda to generate greater profits and pay for school fees for herself. Brenda hopes that in the future she will be able to become a nurse. 

Brenda is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator and washing machine

loans.name: Joice's Group

texts.en:
Joice's group is composed of 4 hard working women. Joice is 21 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Joice has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fresh food like matooke (green plantains).

To help expand her business, Joice has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more fresh food like matooke, cassava and sweet potatoes for resale, and will help Joice to generate greater profits. She will manage to pay some of her child's school fees and buy new clothes for herself and the child. Joice hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house for herself. 

Joice is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more fresh food like matooke, cassava, and sweet potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Donald

texts.en:
Donald is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children who are all currently in school. For the past 3 years, Donald has been working hard to manage his medical clinic. 

To help expand his business, Donald  has requested a loan of 2500000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more medicine for the clinic, and will help Donald generate greater profits and provide medicine for all people in his community. Donald hopes that in the future he will be able to have a fully established clinic with all medical facilities. 

Donald  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Donald who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more medicine for his clinic.

loans.name: Sharon Maria's Group

texts.en:
Sharon's group is comprised of  hard working women. Sharon is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kititale in the region of Uganda. For the past year, Sharon has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells household goods like flour and soap. 

To help expand her business, Sharon has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more goods like sugar and posho to sell, and will help Sharon to generate greater profits and buy more . 

Sharon is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more goods like sugar and posho to sell

loans.name: Shadia's Group

texts.en:
Shadia's group is comprised of 4 hard working women. Shadia is 16 years old and lives in the town of Makidye in the Kampala south region of Uganda. For the past , Shadia has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Shadia has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for resale, and will help Shadia to generate greater profits and save her money for future use. Shadia hopes that in the future she will be able to move out of her parents house and start renting her own. 

Shadia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Lillian

texts.en:
Lillian is 34 years old and lives in the town of Arua Hill in the Arua region of Uganda. She is married and has six children with two of them currently in school. For the past two years, Lillian has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells traditional clothing and saucepans. 

To help expand her business, Lillian has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more traditional clothes and saucepans for her business expansion. It will help Lillian to generate greater profits and educate her children. 

Lillian hopes that in the future she will be able to own another business. 

Lillian is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lillian who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more traditional clothes and saucepans for her business expansion.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is 31 years old and lives in the town of Koboko in the Arua region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past 12 years, Godfrey has been working hard to manage his retail shop.  

To help expand his business, Godfrey has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more commodities such as sugar, soap and wheat flour and will help Godfrey to generate greater profits and buy more stock in bulk at a reduced price. This will help him save more and have a better standard of living. Godfrey hopes that in the future he will be able to own a whole sale shop. 

Godfrey  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Godfrey who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.

loans.use: to purchase more commodities such as sugar, soap, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Serb's Group

texts.en:
Serb is aged 60 years and living with her family members in a rural village located in the Pouk District of Siem Reap Province. She is married with three children. 

Rice farming has been the main source for her family’s income for ten years. Besides farming, she raises four pigs and also sells grocery items in the local area to earn additional income for the family. The current business earns her about 50,000 KHR per day, and she manages to save about 30,000 KHR each day for future needs. Drought is the main challenge for her rice paddy business.

Serb’s group consists of three members, who are a first cycle client with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Now she is leading her group to request a loan with VisionFund of 1,000,000 KHR. Serb, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy pig feed for nourishing her pigs. She hopes to fatten her pigs so as to sell them for a good price to improve her family’s life.

loans.use: to buy pig feed for nourishing her pigs.

loans.name: Savat

texts.en:
A father living in a rural village of the Moung Russey District of Battambang Province, Savat is aged 35 years and married with five children. For fifteen years, Savet has been working as motor taxi driver in the local area while his wife is a rice farmer. Together, they are able to earn about 40,000 KHR per day, and manage to save about 20,000 KHR each day after daily expenses. Insufficient working capital is the main challenge for his current business. 

Savat is in his first loan with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Now he is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 KHR.  He will use this loan to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for his farmland and use a portion of it to spend on gasoline fees for water pumping. Savat hopes this loan will enable him to increase rice yields so as to improve his standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for his farmland.

loans.name: Kimnorn

texts.en:
Living in a wooden house in a rural area of the Ou Reang Ov district of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, Kimnorn is a 28-year-old married woman who has been farming rice as the main source of her family’s income on 1.5-hectare area of farmland for five years. To add more income, she also works as a paid worker in her local area. Her daily income is approximately 15,000 KHR per day and she can manage to save about 5,000 KHR each day after offsetting daily expenses.

Kimnorn is in her first microloan with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. She is requesting a loan of 2,400,000 KHR. She will use this loan to buy fertilizer for her farmland. Through this loan, she hopes to get a high yield from the rice-paddy crop so as to better her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Yan's Group

texts.en:
Yan is 28 years old and originally from Sampov Meas district of Pursat Province. She has three children, two of whom are still under her dependency as they are still in school. For her children's sake, she grows paddy rice and sugarcane. She has engaged in this for several years. Her main challenge is the low yield caused by pests.

Yan and her co-members, who are in the same group of three, have never been with VisionFund before. Now, she forms her group for a new loan. As leader, she is going to use her portion of the new loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide for her crops. She hopes that this purchase will increase her crop production, so she can earn more profit.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and and pesticide

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en: Winfred is a 32-year-old hardworking woman living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is a teacher by profession and also deals in mobile money transfers, which operate like Western Union. The service is intended to help people in rural areas who can not access money through banks. She is serving mobile users, who describe her as an honest and hardworking lady. Winfred is facing the hardship of competition, and her dream is to start a microfinance institution. She is requesting the loan to purchase electronic float for her mobile money business, so that she can process more transactions for her clients on a daily basis.

loans.use: to purchase electronic float for her mobile money business, so that she can process more transactions for her clients on a daily basis

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a 35-year-old man with four children living in Kagadi, Uganda. Like most good fathers he wishes to educate his children to attain degrees as minimum qualification and set up sustainable projects for income sources. For six years he has been running a piggery project. He started with two pigs but now has over 20 pigs and he has sold others. He started the business with his salary savings as a teacher. His business dream is to construct a modern pig sty as the current dwelling is grass thatched. Joseph is requesting for a loan to buy feeds for the pigs.

loans.use: to buy feeds for the pigs.

loans.name: Kimly's Group

texts.en:
A villager residing in a rural area of Kror Kor district of Pursat province, Cambodia, Kimly is a 32-year-old married woman with two children. Both of her children (one daughter and one son) are under her care. To make a living, she has businesses selling Khmer noodles and raising pigs. Her husband also assists in the pig-raising business and, to supplement the family's income, works as a fisherman. Kimly has nine years of experience in her current businesses, earning approximately 14,000KHR per day and managing to save around 8,000KHR for future needs. 

This will be Kimly’s second time requesting a loan with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). The first loan that she received enabled her to buy more pigs to raise and secure food for her family. She has faced challenges such as lacking working capital and unhealthy pigs. Now she is leading her fellow group members, Pov and Lav, to take out a loan with VisionFund. With her requested loan portion, Kimly will buy pig feed and fishing materials, such as fish traps and cast nets. After receiving and using her loan portion, she believes that she will be able to boost her income and use a portion of the income to show the love that she has for her children by educating them; sending them to good school.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and fishing materials.

loans.name: Kunthea's Group

texts.en:
Kunthea is 49 years old and a local farmer, who currently grows rice and pineapple in order to meet the daily cost of living for her entire household, especially her children. Farming rice and pineapple is the business that she has been in for 13 years. 

Kunthea's group is comprised of two female members, and Kunthea is a second-time borrower and the group leader. She has managed her first loan in a wise manner in moving her business forward, and it has returned her a decent income. She and her fellow group member are seeking 1,200,000 KHR and 600,000 KHR, respectively. Kunthea is going to use her entire portion of the loan to buy fertilizer for both of her crops. She hopes to gain a higher yield than before, so she can keep up a good pace of her business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Thoy's Group

texts.en:
Thoy, a 41-year-old married mother, lives in a rural area of the Kror Kor district of Pursat province, Cambodia. She has one child to take care of. To make a living, Thoy has been farming rice and raising pigs for twenty-one years. In addition, she also weaves mats in the local area to earn additional income for her family. The current business earns her approximately 14,000 KHR per day, and she manages to save about 9,000 KHR per day after daily expenses. Insufficient working capital is still the main challenge for supporting her current business.

Thoy has been with VisionFund for five cycles and has completely paid back the past loans, and the other member has been with VisionFund for two cycles. Thoy has wisely used the past loan to improve her family's living conditions, and now she is confident to make a better living. She is leading her group of two to request another loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy pig feed for nourishing her pigs. She hopes to fatten her pigs so that she can sell them for a good price and improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy pig feed for nourishing her pigs

loans.name: Ol

texts.en:
A citizen from a rural village of Battambang province’s Thmor Koul district, Ol is aged 32 years and married with three children (one daughter and three sons), all of whom are dependents and still in school. To make a living and support the family, Ol and her husband have been farming rice on 6 hectares of farmland as a primary business for seven years. Insufficient working capital to support her paddy-field is still the main challenge. 

This is the fifth microloan for Ol with Kiva’s partner VisionFund. She completely paid back the past loans, which have helped her better support her family with sufficient foods. 

Now she is requesting a loan of $1,000. Ol will use this loan to buy rice seeds and fertilizer for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to cultivate her rice to earn more income to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds and fertilizer for her farmland.

loans.name: Maly's Group

texts.en: Maly, age 31 and married, is one of the breadwinner in the family consisting of herself and four children. Two of her children are students, while the remaining two work for other people, for a fee. Her four years' experience in rice farming enable her to earn about 26,000 KHR per day. This is the first loan for both Maly and her co-member. They are applying for 250,000 KHR each. Maly, the group leader, is going to buy rice seed for her farm. She hopes to grow her crop on time, so that she can make good progress of her living conditions, gradually.

loans.use: To buy rice seed for her farm

loans.name: Pos

texts.en:
Pos, 63, lives with her husband and six children in a rural village of the Thmor Koul district, Cambodia. To support the family, Pos and her husband earn a living as farmers. They have been farming rice on two hectares of farmland for twenty years, earning about 30,000 KHR per day and managing to save about 15,000 KHR each day after off-setting daily expenses.

Pos is in her first loan with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. She is applying for a loan of 610,000 KHR. With this loan, she is going to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes to increase her crop yields so as to generate more income to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland.

loans.name: Soem's Group

texts.en: Soem is 51 years old and married. To cover the daily cost of living for her children, she grows rice on five hectares of farmland, with support from her husband. She has been in rice farming for 10 years. This is the fifth loan cycle for Soem, and the third loan cycle for her co-member in the group of two. Soem's past loan, which she has completely repaid, relieved her family's burdens and improved its livelihood. Now, she is the leader of the group to apply for a new loan. She will use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline and insecticide for her rice farm. She hopes to gain a yield better than last year's, so she can keep a good pace of her lifestyle as well as her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, gasoline and insecticide for her rice farm

loans.name: Sarun's Group

texts.en: Sarun is 50 years old and a widow mother of five children. Two of her children still depends on her as they are still in school. The rest of her family is from Kror Kor district of Pursat Province. Her main income is from her one and half hectare of rice cropping, which she has engaged in for 13 years.This is the fifth-cycle loan for Sarun and fourth-cycle loan for her fellow group member; both of them are in the same group of two. She has used her past loan in a wise manner in providing a decent food for her entire household. Now, she is seeking for 600,000 KHR and  her co-member is requesting for 700,000 KHR. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer and rice seed for her farmland. She expects to multiply her crop output and earn a high profit for her children sake.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Sokkim's Group

texts.en:
Sokkim, a single woman from Sa Ang district of Kandal Province, has struggled to survive daily living through working as a farmer and as a paid worker for extra income. Both of these current businesses earn her about 12,300 KHR per day. Sokkim has been with VisionFund for two loan cycles and has successfully paid back the past loans. These have helped her to maintain her household, especially with decent food. Now, she and one of her co-members are applying for 1,000,000 KHR each, while a remaining member is seeking 600,000 KHR. 

As the group leader, her loan portion will be used for buying fertilizer, gasoline for water pumping, and to pay for the plowing fee. She hopes that she will get a high yield with high income, so she can keep maintaining her household.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, gasoline for water pumping, and to pay for the plowing fee.

loans.name: Lorenzo

texts.es: El señor Lorenzo, es una persona de 33 años de edad de estado civil soltero pero vive en concubinato, alcanzo a estudiar una carreta profesional en la Universidad a nivel de Ing. Agronómica, vive junto a su familia en su casa propia que se halla situado en la población de Tíraque, distante aproximadamente desde la ciudad de Cochabamba a 65 Km. y cuenta con dos dependientes económicos a cargo los cuales son sus pequeños hijos. El cliente presta sus servicios profesionales como jefe de agencia en una cooperativa desde hace  4 años, de Tíraque por el cual percibe un salario fijo mensual. Y finalmente el cliente tiene el deseo de construir una vivienda más en su domicilio y para tal efecto se ve en la necesidad de solicitar capital para realizar la compra de materiales de construcción y de tal manera poder mejorar las condiciones de habitad de su familia.
texts.en: Lorenzo is 33 years old. His civil status is single, but he lives with his partner. He was able to study a professional degree at university in agricultural engineering. He lives with his family in their own house, which is located in the town of Tíraque, about 65 kilometers from Cochabamba. He has two financial dependents, which are his two small children. For four years, Lorenzo has provided his professional services as agency head of a cooperative in Tíraque. He receives a monthly salary for this. Lastly, Lorenzo would like to expand the housing of his current home, and therefore needs to request capital to be purchase the construction materials. In this way, he will be able to improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials to expand his family's housing.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en: Mary Grace is a 40-year-old married mother with two children. She has been in the variety store business for more than six years now. She is asking for a loan worth 10000 PHP to buy milk, cooking oil, biscuits and soft drinks. Mary Grace dreams of making her business a success and continually support the schooling of her children.

loans.use: buy items to sell in her store

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza is a good and responsible mother to her children. She loves her family and will sacrifice everything for them. She has operated a general store business since she was 21 years old. She is now 35 years old and married to Rolly, who has been engaged in a furniture business for eight years. They now have two children. They reside in San Ignacio province of Isabela. 

Flordeliza  knows that her business is of great help in sending her children to school and providing for the needs of her family.  She is hoping that someday, through her business, she can continue to provide for the educational needs of her children. For her to fullfil her dreams, she would like to borrow a loan of PHP 25,000.00 that she can use for the development of her store.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, noodles, coffee and sugar for her store

loans.name: Maa Durga Self Help Group

texts.en:
The group Maa Durga Self Help Group (SHG) has 13 members who are all from the same neighbourhood. The lady wearing  a light blue  saree standing in left side of photograph is Mata who is the leader of the group. Mata is a 38-year-old woman married to a fisherman of Balugaon village in Odisha, India. The couple has a son who is in school. Mata lives with her son and together with her husband takes care of all the household expenses. She helps her husband in selling the fish. Her husband goes to the lake every morning for fishing and she sells those fish in the market as fresh fish and keeps some of them for drying. (Drying the fish is a way of preserving the fish for future use.  It is done by drying them in the sun until water is completely evaporated.) Demand for dry as well as fresh fish is very high in the region. 

All other members of this group are also engaged in selling fresh and dry fish in the market. In order to strengthen the business and respond to client demand, Mata together with her group Maa Durga SHG has requested for a loan amount of 260,000 INR for purchasing a storage box for fish and a fishing net. Their goal is to increase their business activity.

loans.use: to purchase a storage box for fish and a fishing net.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette offers a variety of homemade delicacies such as leche flan, ube and native cakes. She has been doing this business for 20 years. According to her, she sells her products within her village, and she also supplies selected fast food establishments in Santiago City. Since her business is growing, she is in need of additional working capital. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of 6,000 PHP, which will allow her to buy stocks of flour, condensed milk, sugar and plastic covers for her food production sales. 

She hopes to obtain this loan so she can supply all her customers and improve the quality of her homemade delicacies. In this way, she can gain better profits, enabling her to save some for emergency purposes and send her two children to a higher level of education.

loans.use: to buy flour, condensed milk, sugar and plastic covers for her food production sales.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es: La señora Antonia cliente empezó con una atención de servicio de te en un pequeño kiosco  en la localidad de Chimoré, poco a poco fue estableciendo clientes con el servicio de té y café. Con el pasar del tiempo se aprovisiono de equipos pequeños para repostería, también recibió capacitación de las ONG´S para preparación de empanadas, salteñas, tortas, etc., así en su inquietud de poder incrementar su producción la cliente quiere  atender la demanda de sus clientes que fue creciendo y que ahora es una oportunidad para poder incrementar en equipos y así pueda producir mejor y con mayor cantidad. En consecuencia el crédito KIVA que se le ofrece a la cliente será de gran ayuda. Ahora la señora Antonia contara con una heladera lo que hará que su actividad crezca y se desarrolle más.
texts.en: Antonia started out selling tea from a small kiosk in the town of Chimoré.  Little by little she began attracting customers with her tea and coffee service.  Over time, she has added small bakery equipment and received training from NGO's in the preparation of pies, meat pies, cakes, etc.  She is anxious to increase production to be able to meet the demand of her customers, so she wants to take advantage of the opportunity to buy more equipment and produce more volume.  The KIVA loan she receives will be of great help because now Antonia will have a refrigerator to help grow and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator.

loans.name: Kausar

texts.en:
Ms Kausar is a 41-year-old vigorous lady and a mother of three. She has had a business of stitching for 8 years. She is famous for stitching fine clothes in her community.  Initially she earned a low income, but with the passage of time her business income has increased, which is only due to her passion to give a better future to her kids. She is illiterate, so she wants to see her children well educated. Her husband is a laborer and his monthly income is not sufficient to fulfill the needs of the family members.

Kausar has one machine and now she wants to purchase one more sewing machine for her daughter, to increase sewing capacity. For this she requested a loan of Rs.35,000. She hopes that her family income will be increased and they will be able to manage their households. She dreams of sending her children to school. Her husband is very happy to see the increasing growth of her business.

loans.use: To purchase one more sewing machine.

loans.name: Kimsan's Group

texts.en:
Kimsan, a 25-year-old married father, lives in a rural area of the Dambae district of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. He has no children. 

To make a living, he has been growing cassava on 2.5 hectares of farmland for one year. The current business earns him approximately 40,000 KHR per day and he manages to save about 20,000 KHR each day after daily expenses.
 
This is the first group loan for Kimsan with VisionFund. He is leading his group of two to ask for a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, he is going to use his portion to pay for labor fees. Kimsan hopes to get a high yield so as to sell it for a good price in order to make a living better.

loans.use: To pay for labor fees.

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is a 23-year-old married woman with two children. She would like to start growing vegetables to earn a living. Dorothy has requested a loan to buy vegetable seeds, chemicals, a shovel, and gloves to start her business. 

She has been a member of SPBD for three years. Dorothy will spend her profits to pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy vegetable seeds, chemicals, a shovel, and gloves.

loans.name: Seur's Group

texts.en:
Seur, 48, is a villager from the Srey Snom District of Siem Reap Province, where crop farming is a common way to earn a living. She is married and has two children. Rice farming is the main source of her family's income.  She and her husband have been doing this for five years to make a living. With her current business, she can earn about KHR 10,000 per day and save about KHR 5,000 each day for future needs. 

This is Seur's group's fourth loan with VisionFund, and she has been a member of VisionFund for two cycles already, while her co-member has been with VisionFund for one cycle. The past loans from VisionFund have helped her better support her living. After successful loan repayment, she is confident of making her own living, and she is now leading her group to apply for a loan. Seur will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland and use a portion of it for house improvement. 

She hopes to grow her rice fruitfully and healthily and also hopes to make a better living .

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland.

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en: Ms. Tahira is a 44-year-old, married woman. Twelve years ago, she started her own business of selling cloth for bed sheets, pillows and quilts etc., when her husband got severely ill. She buys cloths(fabric) of different designs from the market in bulk at lower rates and sells them in her community. She counts a good client list; most of her clients are her neighbors. However these days she is facing difficulties of low cash in hand. This compelled her to contact Kashf Foundation upon the advice of her neighbor to meet her business requirements. Ms. Tahira is a mother of six children, two of them go to school. She wishes to send her other children to school, but is unable to cover the expenses. Now she has requested for a loan of 45,000 PKR. She is going to use this loan to buy an ample variety of cloths(fabric) in different colors and designs to add to her current ones. She expects aboost in her net income and intends to use the earned profits on her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy an ample variety of cloths in different colors and designs to add to her current ones.

loans.name: Ferdinand

texts.en:
Ferdinand is 31 years old and has two children he is sending to school. He is married to Marissa and they live in Enrile. Ferdinand grows rice to sell to traders in their village. Ferdinand gains about P10,000 each harvest season, twice a year. 

He would like to improve his production so he is now asking for a loan of P15,000 to buy fertilizers and pesticides to use in the farming business. 

Someday, with good profits and abundant harvests, he will give a good education to his children, which is necessary to acquire better employment someday.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides to use in the farming business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy shuttering materials like supporting pipes, bamboos etc

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en:
Sambath is 52 years old. She is married and resides with one child in Battambang Province, Cambodia. She has been selling sweet cake which is made of sticky rice, banana and pumpkin for more than two years, earning approximately $10 daily. Her husband helps her run the business. Her child is a singer who earns about $6 each day. 

Due to the difficulty in her family’s transportation, Sambath is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike for commuting. This purchase will help her reduce the transportation expenses. In the future, she would like to expand her business and build a new house.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Nhaet's Group

texts.en:
Nhaet is a young mother of two children originally from Moung Russey district, Cambodia. 

To overcome her family's hardship, she and her husband grow rice, pineapple, and chilies. She has been in this business for about five years, earning about 20,000 KHR per day. 

Nhaet's group consists of two female members and both of them have been with VisionFund at least for one cycle. Her past loan was the original loan and she has paid it back with success. Her past loan helped to support her business and maintain her living conditions. 

Now, she is seeking a 1,000,000 KHR loan, the same amount as her co-member. As a group leader, she will buy fertilizer for her crops. She hopes to earn more yields and a better profit.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her crops.

loans.name: Taman Sari Group

texts.en:
The Taman Sari Group is located in the village of Pejarakan, North Bali. This area receives very little rainfall, so for this dry season a lot of the farmers' produce was not optimal. Seeing this situation, the Taman Sari group, which consisted of 10 women, took the initiative to develop pigs in an effort to support the family economy.

Luh Eka, the head of the group, has two children. After successfully selling previous piglets, she now requests a loan to buy three local piglets to become a pig barbeque. Pigs are maintained for two months and then are ready for sale. The profits will be used to buy another pig, so after sixth months she will be able to start repayments on the loan. She hopes these efforts will help her husband's income from working as a farmer.

loans.use: To buy three local piglets to be a pig roll.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita is married, 38 years of age, and lives in Poblacion, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental, together with her five kids. Anita is operating a sari-sari (convenience) store to earn a living. She has been in this business for more than five years and she earns 4,000 PHP every month. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps etc. Anita's business is very stable in her community. She joined GDMPC this year. In the future, Anita will use her income to support her five kids in their studies until they finish college, and also to meet their daily needs. Anita wishes that her business would be more progressive.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps etc

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga is 48 years old. She is married and has three children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Dominga has been raising pigs for 11 years and she also earns additional income from a general store and the sale of gasoline. She is borrowing 23,000 PHP through NWTF in order to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream which is to save money in order to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Than

texts.en:
Than was born in 1960. She has six children. Her five daughters are adults. Her son is learning at high school. She and her husband raise chickens and grow rice to earn a living. Than is also a bricklayer to earn more money for her family. Her income is about 4,500,000 VND. Her family’s total earnings are about 13,500,000 VND per month. 

Than has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2006. In the last cycle she borrowed 8,502,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy food for chickens. She always wants to enlarge her chicken farm.

loans.use: to buy food for chickens.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en: Marina is a 53-year-old farmer from the town of Trinidad, Bohol. She is a widow who primarily grows rice for an income for 10 years now. Aside from farming, she is also engaged in baking bread for additional income. She is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer as well as the flour, cooking oil and baking powder that is needed so she can produce more bread. She hopes that through the loan, she can improve her business profit and the life of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, flour, cooking oil and baking powder.

loans.name: Concesa

texts.en:
This is Concesa, 57, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Lapito, who is a father to her children. By the grace of God and with the help of her supportive husband, she can provide the needs of her children. She is able to do so by means of small business enterprises that she ventures into.

Concesa’s business is an arcade shop. In the Philippines - especially in urban poor communities - not all families can afford to buy personal computers, portable play stations, or equipment for video games. Children only enjoy this kind of amusement by renting at computer arcades and they pay per hour of usage. She also has a variety store. She has several arcade units and she earns 500 PHP per day. 

To help her continue running her business, she is requesting a 35,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to pay for spare parts and the maintenance of her arcade. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Concesa hopes to be able to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of giving her children a good and quality education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.
